title: 115_hr2857
content: The Act is titled the "Supporting Families in Substance Abuse Treatment Act" and it pertains to foster care maintenance payments for children with parents in licensed residential family-based treatment facilities for substance abuse. Children placed with a parent in a licensed residential family-based treatment facility for substance abuse may be eligible for foster care maintenance payments for up to 12 months. Children placed in a licensed residential family-based treatment facility for substance abuse may receive foster care maintenance payments for up to 12 months if the placement is part of the child's case plan, includes parenting skills training, counseling, and is trauma-informed. The State may receive payment for children placed with a parent in a licensed residential family-based treatment facility for substance abuse, with the amount not exceeding what would be received for placement in a different setting. Only children meeting specific requirements are eligible for foster care maintenance payments. The State may receive payment for children placed in a licensed residential family-based treatment facility for substance abuse, with the amount not exceeding what would be received for placement in a different setting. Children meeting specific requirements are eligible for foster care maintenance payments. Section 474(a)(1) of the Act is amended to include a conforming amendment. The effective date for the amendments regarding foster care maintenance payments is specified in Section 3. The amendments made by this Act will take effect on October 1, 2017, with a transition rule for State plans under part E of title IV of the Social Security Act. The Act will take effect on October 1, 2017, with a transition rule for State plans under part E of title IV of the Social Security Act. In the case of a State with a 2-year legislative session, each year is considered a separate session. For Indian tribal organizations needing time to comply with the Act, the Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide necessary assistance. The Secretary will provide additional time for tribes, organizations, or tribal consortiums to comply with requirements before being considered non-compliant. Passed the House of Representatives on June 20, 2017. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk.
